body: wow. got it.

What do you propose? I am sorry, I read your description, and can't follow the case. The issue was from old history(3.2.x), I think we have a conflict patch plugin for that case already. But what is your case?

skywalking java agent : v8.7.0
springboot version: 2.4.6
When I use skywalking java agent, my project start failed.  I found that when a controller has only one private constructor with parameters, the problem can be reproduced. I think the reason is agent ignored the constructor without distinguish whether the constructor is custom or by interceptor fill out. [AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor](https://github.com/apache/skywalking-java/blob/main/apm-sniffer/apm-sdk-plugin/spring-plugins/core-patch/src/main/java/org/apache/skywalking/apm/plugin/spring/patch/AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor.java)（line 75,  `if (!Modifier.isPrivate(constructor.getModifiers())) {`）

OK, this is rare to see in practice. But I am not sure what is a good way to check whether this private constructor is yours or not. Do you have any suggestions? Maybe check the type of constructor's parameter?

Currently, I have informed my colleague not to write controller like this. I am not familiar with the mechanism of `AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor`, and I think the way the constructor parameters are checked is tricky, but i don not have a better way yet.

> The ui templates, e2e cases need to be updated.

okay.
Why do we suddenly change this? I am fine but just curious.
This could break 3rd party integration, so, I want to know why.

> Why do we suddenly change this? I am fine but just curious.

In order to make the user experience better, for example, when users configure alarm rules, the avg response time of the endpoint can be configured as naturally as the avg response time of the service/instance, rather than making `endpoint_avg` unique. It looks a bit weird, and users will think that there is something specially designed in it?

> This could break 3rd party integration, so, I want to know why.

If it involves large changes or coordination troubles, we can still use the original name

> > Why do we suddenly change this? I am fine but just curious.
> 
> 
> 
> In order to make the user experience better, for example, when users configure alarm rules, the avg response time of the endpoint can be configured as naturally as the avg response time of the service/instance, rather than making `endpoint_avg` unique. It looks a bit weird, and users will think that there is something specially designed in it?

No specific reason. I believe this is a mistake. If we plan to fix, let us be clear this is a break change in the change log, and search all docs, whether OAL and alarm docs affected by this break.

> > > Why do we suddenly change this? I am fine but just curious.
> > 
> > 
> > In order to make the user experience better, for example, when users configure alarm rules, the avg response time of the endpoint can be configured as naturally as the avg response time of the service/instance, rather than making `endpoint_avg` unique. It looks a bit weird, and users will think that there is something specially designed in it?
> 
> No specific reason. I believe this is a mistake. If we plan to fix, let us be clear this is a break change in the change log, and search all docs, whether OAL and alarm docs affected by this break.

Okay

@adaivskenan I think the problem is that Spring didn't recognize this private constructor. Maybe you can try to upgrade your spring boot to 2.5.x. `AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor` will give priority to constructors recognized by Spring. Only when Spring does not recognize the constructor, `AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor` will analyze the constructor of the current class and ignore the private one.

I want to add a notice this although I am totally fine about this change.

This template update was introduced due to metric indices merging, not for forward compatibility. So, even we open this feature to all indices, some break changes are still there, such as [v9 upgrade doc](https://skywalking.apache.org/docs/main/latest/en/faq/v9-version-upgrade/#v9-upgrade) described. 

This is a nice-to-have thing, but legacy data will still be an issue for newer kernal.

@wallezhang The problem still exists after upgrading the SpringBoot version, Thank you for explaining the mechanism of AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor. If no agent is used, Spring can identify the constructor, and the condition is `rawCandidates.length == 1 && rawCandidates[0].getParameterCount() > 0`. If the agent is used, the rawCandidates will become 2 (including the one created by skywalking java agent), and Spring will have no conditions that can be met to recognize the constructor. [AutowiredAnnotationBeanPostProcessor](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/5.3.x/spring-beans/src/main/java/org/springframework/beans/factory/annotation/AutowiredAnnotationBeanPostProcessor.java)](line 375).
I think `AutowiredAnnotationProcessorInterceptor` should ignored the constructor created by skywalking java agent by judging where the constructor  is synthetic or not @wu-sheng . And I tried this solution, it works.
@adaivskenan Could you send a pull request to share which way you chose to skip the agent-created constructor? If it is widely suitable, I am good to have that in the upstream.

> @ldy If you use the default plugin or have imported gateway related plugins ，spring-cloud-gateway（reactor-netty） cannot print traceId，this is because these plugins are all in beforeMethod and delete trace. If you want to print that traceId，you can import spring-annotation-plugin，but this cannot solve the problem that your logback traceId in ResponseBobyGatewayFilter cannot be printed，because you are an asynchronous callback method. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40192576/101980550-2a2e2300-3ca1-11eb-8faf-a6f35bb3a58f.png)

use the FunctionWrapper which under the apm-toolkit-trace lib, it looks like can fix the asynchronous callback missing the trace id problem.

@kezhenxu94 I noticed 2 issues here.
1. It seems random is not supported. Is this a doc error or code bug?
2. NextRandom should have performance issue AFAIK. Current thread random should be better.
3. With security concern, I think we should set native Util APIs to bridge all supported methods, if (1) is limited to call Java method directly(Not sure).

> @kezhenxu94 I noticed 2 issues here.
> 
> 1. It seems random is not supported. Is this a doc error or code bug?

I'd say this is by design, we never allow users to call arbitrary Java methods in LAL.

> 3. With security concern, I think we should set native Util APIs to bridge all supported methods, if (1) is limited to call Java method directly(Not sure).

For this specific case, I'd rather provide a dedicated sampler (for example called `percentage`), letting users to call `Math.*` methods is easy but in LAL I don't see there are many other applicable cases, and I'm concerned users might overuse them (performance issues).

What do you think @WuChang-GitHub @wu-sheng if we provide a dedicated sampler (`percentage`) and hold for a while to add those bridge methods?

Hi @kezhenxu94 @Superskyyy , after some research, I don't think skywalking-python has any problem, it's uWSGI that needs special treatment, this solution below can solve my problem, including issues https://github.com/apache/skywalking/issues/6324.
```python
from uwsgidecorators import postfork
from skywalking import agent, config

@postfork
def init_tracing():
    config.protocol = 'grpc'
    config.init(collector_address='xxxxx', service_name='test-1')
    config.flask_collect_http_params = True
    config.logging_level = 'DEBUG'
    agent.start()

from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)


@app.route('/')
def hello_world():
    return 'Hello World!'


if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run()
```

From [uWSGI doc](https://uwsgi-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/PythonDecorators.html#uwsgidecorators.postfork) we can know 
> uWSGI is a preforking (or “fork-abusing”) server, so you might need to execute a fixup task after each fork(). The postfork decorator is just the ticket. You can declare multiple postfork tasks. Each decorated function will be executed in sequence after each fork().

Do you have a better solution? Maybe we can note this in skywalking's documentation, after all uWsgi is a popular library.

@arcosx Hello, great to see you found a solution, would you mind opening a PR to document this? I believe it is valuable since both packages are widely used, and from our observation, the issue occurs rather frequently. Probably this should go to the FAQ folder, with a doc name of your choice. https://github.com/apache/skywalking-python/tree/master/docs/en/setup/faq

Hi @ethan256 , thanks for raising this, actually, this is by design and the doc is kind of outdated,

```
- times: How many times to trigger the action, 0=infinite.
```

this should be: "how many times to trigger the action before aborting if the trigger failed, or continue if the trigger succeeded"
@ethan256 would you like to open a pull request to fix the doc?
